title: GeeksforGeeks Student Chapter | SRM IST, Kattankulathur
author: Aayush Rai
description: An overview of the GeeksforGeeks Student Chapter at SRM IST, Kattankulathur, including its mission, events, opportunities, achievements, and how to join.
content:
## **Introduction**
The **GeeksforGeeks Student Chapter at SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur** is a vibrant and active coding community dedicated to helping students **enhance their problem-solving skills**, **learn development**, and **prepare for placements**. Our mission is to create a collaborative space for students to **learn, build, and grow** in the field of technology.

---

## **About the Chapter**
- **Founded At:** SRM IST, Kattankulathur
- **Objective:** Build a strong coding culture and bridge the gap between academics and industry.
- **Community Strength:** 500+ active members
- **Focus Areas:** DSA, Web Development, AI/ML, Competitive Programming, and Interview Preparation.

---

## **Mission & Vision**
- **Learn by Doing:** Hands-on workshops, live coding sessions, and projects.
- **Prepare for Placements:** Focused on DSA, problem-solving, and mock interviews.
- **Build Together:** Encourage collaborative projects and open-source contributions.
- **Stay Updated:** Industry talks and sessions with experienced developers and alumni.

---

## **Events & Programs**
### **💻 Technical Workshops**
- Beginner to advanced sessions on **DSA, Web Development, AI/ML**, and **Next.js**.
- Hands-on labs to implement concepts in real-time.

### **🏆 Coding Contests**
- Monthly coding challenges and hackathons.
- Problem-solving practice on the **GeeksforGeeks platform**.

### **🎤 Expert Talks**
- Sessions conducted by **industry professionals, SRM alumni, and GfG experts**.
- Insights on internships, product-based companies, and competitive programming.

### **🤝 Peer-to-Peer Mentorship**
- Small cohort-based mentorship led by senior students.
- One-on-one doubt-solving sessions and personalized guidance.

---

## **How to Join**
Becoming a part of the **GfG Student Chapter** is simple and **completely free**:
- **Step 1:** Fill out the official registration form (released at the start of every semester).
- **Step 2:** Join the WhatsApp/Discord group for updates.
- **Step 3:** Attend the orientation and choose your preferred track.

> Walk-in registrations are also available for selected events and bootcamps.

---

## **Core Team & Roles**
- **President & Vice-President:** Manage chapter strategy and collaborations.
- **Tech Leads:** Lead DSA, development, and AI/ML programs.
- **Events Team:** Organize workshops, hackathons, and contests.
- **Content & Design Team:** Create event posters, blogs, and social media content.
- **Sponsorship & Outreach Team:** Build partnerships with companies and other clubs.

> **Recruitments** happen once every semester through forms, short tasks, and interviews.

---

## **Achievements**
- **500+ participants** in coding bootcamps and workshops.
- Alumni placed in **MAANG, Oracle, Atlassian, Razorpay, Zomato**, and other top tech companies.
- Conducted **15+ successful workshops** and **6 hackathons** in the past year.
- Community-built open-source tools and templates shared via GitHub.

---

## **Upcoming Event Calendar (Odd Semester 2025)**
- **Week 1:** Orientation + Git & GitHub Workshop
- **Week 2–5:** DSA Bootcamp — Arrays, Strings, Hashing, Two Pointers
- **Week 6–9:** Advanced DSA — Trees, Graphs, DP
- **Week 10:** Web Development Sprint — Next.js + APIs
- **Week 11:** HackSRM — 24-hour hackathon
- **Week 12:** Placement Prep Series — Mock Interviews & Resume Reviews

---

## **Conclusion**
The **GeeksforGeeks Student Chapter at SRM IST, KTR** is more than just a club — it's a **community of passionate learners** working together to become better engineers. Whether you're a beginner looking to learn DSA or a senior preparing for placements, GfG SRM offers **resources, mentorship, and opportunities** to help you grow.

> "Code. Collaborate. Conquer."

title: My Journey as a CSE Student | Aayush Rai
author: Aayush Rai
description: A detailed look into my academic journey, achievements, and profile as a CSE student specializing in AIML.
content:
## **Introduction**
Hi, I'm **Aayush Rai**, a passionate **Computer Science and Engineering** student specializing in **Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning (AIML)** at **SRM University, Kattankulathur**. My aim is to become a skilled software engineer and build a strong technical foundation during my B.Tech.

---

## **Academic Journey**
- **Schooling:** Completed my 12th grade from **Birla Public School, Pilani** in **April 2024**.
- **12th Percentage:** **91.2%** in **PCM**.
- **Current Course:** Pursuing **B.Tech in CSE (AIML)** at **SRM University**.
- **Year:** 2nd Year (2025)
- **First-Year CGPA:** **9.51 / 10**

---

## **Achievements & Roles**
### **🎓 Academic Achievements**
- Scored **91.2%** in **Class 12 (PCM)**.
- Secured **9.51 CGPA** in the **first year** of B.Tech.
- Consistently ranked among the top students in academics.

### **🏅 Leadership & Extracurriculars**
- Served as the **Academic Prefect** at Birla Public School, Pilani, leading academic activities and mentoring peers.
- **Hosted and anchored multiple events and functions**, including cultural programs, school assemblies, and annual functions.
- Actively participated in debates, presentations, and technical workshops.

### **💻 Technical Skills**
- **Languages:** C, C++, Python, JavaScript
- **Web Development:** Next.js, React, Tailwind CSS, Node.js
- **Databases:** MySQL, MongoDB
- **Specialization:** Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning

---

## **GATE CSE 2027 Preparation**
I have started preparing for **GATE CSE 2027** as a long-term academic objective. Right now I’m focusing on strengthening core CS fundamentals, especially:
- **Data Structures & Algorithms (DSA)**
- **Operating Systems (OS)**
- **Computer Organization & Architecture (COA)**
- **Discrete Mathematics**

 While GATE is on the roadmap, my immediate priority is solidifying fundamentals and building practical projects.

---

## **Conclusion**
My journey so far has been about **hard work, consistency, and balanced growth**—from strong academic results to leadership and hosting events. I’m committed to learning continuously and applying my skills to real projects and challenges.

> "Dream big, work hard, and stay consistent. Success will follow."

title: Responsive Design with Tailwind CSS
author: Aayush Rai
description: Build fully responsive websites using Tailwind CSS utilities.
content:
**Tailwind CSS** makes **responsive web design** extremely simple by providing **mobile-first utility classes**. Instead of writing complex CSS media queries, you can quickly build layouts that adapt to different screen sizes using Tailwind's **breakpoints** and **flexible utilities**. In this guide, we’ll explore how to create responsive designs using Tailwind CSS with examples and best practices. --- **📌 What Is Responsive Design?** Responsive design ensures that your website **adapts to different screen sizes** — from mobile phones to desktops — for a **seamless user experience**. **Key Benefits:** - Better **user experience** - Improved **SEO rankings** - Easier **maintenance** - Consistent design across devices --- **🎨 Tailwind CSS Breakpoints** Tailwind follows a **mobile-first approach**. You start with the smallest screen styles and then **scale up** using breakpoints. **Default Breakpoints:** | Prefix | Min Width | Device Type | |--------|-----------|-------------| | `sm:` | 640px | Small devices | | `md:` | 768px | Tablets | | `lg:` | 1024px | Laptops | | `xl:` | 1280px | Desktops | | `2xl:` | 1536px | Large screens | **Example:** ```html

Responsive Heading

``` Here: - Default text size: `text-xl` - On **small screens** (`sm:`): `text-2xl` - On **medium screens** (`md:`): `text-3xl` - On **large screens** (`lg:`): `text-4xl` --- **🛠️ Responsive Layouts with Flexbox** Tailwind makes it easy to create responsive **flex layouts**. ```html
Box 1
Box 2
Box 3
``` **How it works:** - Default: **column layout** (`flex-col`) - On small screens (`sm:`): Switches to **row layout** --- **📐 Responsive Grid Layouts** Tailwind also provides **grid utilities** for building adaptive layouts. ```html
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
``` **How it works:** - On **mobile**: 1 column - On **small screens**: 2 columns - On **medium screens**: 3 columns --- **📱 Responsive Images & Media** Making images responsive is straightforward in Tailwind. ```html ``` **Explanation:** - `w-full` → Image takes **full width** of its container - `max-w-md` → Limits maximum width - `mx-auto` → Centers image horizontally --- **⚡ Best Practices for Responsive Design** - Always follow **mobile-first** development - Use **Tailwind's utility classes** instead of writing custom CSS - Prefer **flex** and **grid** for layouts - Test your design on **multiple screen sizes** - Use `container` and `max-w-*` classes to maintain readability --- **🎯 Conclusion** Tailwind CSS makes **responsive design** faster, easier, and more efficient. By leveraging **breakpoints**, **flexbox**, **grid systems**, and **utility classes**, you can build **mobile-friendly, scalable, and modern UIs** without writing complex CSS. Start designing your next **responsive website** with **Tailwind CSS** and experience the difference!

title: Next.js: SSR vs SSG Explained
author: Aayush Rai
description: Understand the difference between Server-Side Rendering and Static Site Generation in Next.js.
content:
**Next.js** is a powerful **React framework** that supports multiple **data-fetching strategies**. Among them, the two most important are **SSR (Server-Side Rendering)** and **SSG (Static Site Generation)**.

In this blog, we’ll understand **how they work**, **when to use each**, and their **performance impact**.

---

**📌 What is SSR (Server-Side Rendering)?**
**Server-Side Rendering** generates the **HTML on the server** for **every incoming request**.

**How it works:**
- The server fetches data → generates HTML → sends it to the browser
- The page is **fresh** and always **up-to-date**

**Example in Next.js:**
```javascript
export async function getServerSideProps() {
  const res = await fetch('https://api.example.com/posts');
  const data = await res.json();

  return { props: { data } };
}
```

**Pros:**
- Always serves **fresh data**
- Better for **personalized content**
- SEO-friendly

**Cons:**
- Slower initial load time
- Higher server load

---

**📌 What is SSG (Static Site Generation)?**
**Static Site Generation** builds the **HTML at build time** and serves the **pre-rendered pages** to users.

**Example in Next.js:**
```javascript
export async function getStaticProps() {
  const res = await fetch('https://api.example.com/posts');
  const data = await res.json();

  return { props: { data } };
}
```

**Pros:**
- **Faster page loads** since pages are pre-rendered
- **Better scalability**
- Low server costs

**Cons:**
- Data may become **stale**
- Re-deployment needed to update content (unless ISR is used)

---

**📌 SSR vs SSG: Key Differences**
| Feature         | SSR                       | SSG                    |
|-----------------|----------------------------|-------------------------|
| Rendering Time  | On **every request**      | At **build time**      |
| Performance    | Slower                     | Faster                 |
| Freshness      | Always up-to-date          | May get stale          |
| Use Case       | Dashboards, profiles, live data | Blogs, docs, marketing pages |

---

**📌 Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR)**
Next.js also provides **ISR**, combining **SSG’s speed** with **SSR’s freshness**.

```javascript
export async function getStaticProps() {
  const res = await fetch('https://api.example.com/posts');
  const data = await res.json();

  return {
    props: { data },
    revalidate: 10 // re-generates page every 10 seconds
  };
}
```

**Best of both worlds!** ✅

---

**🎯 Conclusion**
- Use **SSR** → when data **changes frequently**
- Use **SSG** → for **static, SEO-friendly** pages
- Use **ISR** → when you want **SSG performance** + **SSR freshness**

Understanding these strategies helps you **optimize performance** and **improve SEO** in **Next.js applications**.

title: React Performance Optimization Techniques
author: Aayush Rai
description: Boost your React app's performance using advanced optimization strategies.
content:
**React** is fast by default, but as applications grow, **performance issues** can arise due to **unnecessary re-renders**, **large bundle sizes**, or **heavy DOM updates**. Here’s a guide to optimize **React app performance** effectively. --- **📌 1. Use React.memo() to Avoid Unnecessary Re-renders** Wrap functional components with `React.memo` to **cache results** and **skip re-renders** when props don't change. ```javascript const Button = React.memo(({ onClick, label }) => { console.log('Rendered!'); return ; }); ``` ✅ **Benefit:** Improves performance for components with **stable props**. --- **📌 2. Use useCallback & useMemo Hooks** These hooks **optimize expensive calculations** and **prevent function recreation**. ```javascript const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => heavyComputation(), []); const memoizedHandler = useCallback(() => doSomething(), []); ``` ✅ **Benefit:** Reduces **re-renders** and **optimizes computation-heavy components**. --- **📌 3. Code Splitting with React.lazy() & Suspense** Load components **on demand** instead of bundling everything. ```javascript const Chart = React.lazy(() => import('./Chart')); Loading...

}> ``` ✅ **Benefit:** Reduces **initial bundle size** and **improves load speed**. --- **📌 4. Virtualize Large Lists** For huge datasets, use libraries like **react-window** or **react-virtualized**. ```javascript import { FixedSizeList as List } from 'react-window'; {({ index, style }) =>
Item {index}
} ``` ✅ **Benefit:** Renders **only visible items**, improving performance. --- **📌 5. Optimize Images & Assets** - Use **Next.js Image Optimization** - Prefer **WebP** format - Use **CDN caching** --- **📌 6. Use Profiler for Performance Monitoring** React provides a **Profiler** to find slow components: ```javascript import { Profiler } from 'react'; console.log(info)}> ``` ✅ **Benefit:** Identifies **performance bottlenecks** quickly. --- **🎯 Conclusion** By using **memoization**, **code splitting**, **virtualization**, and **lazy loading**, you can **significantly improve React app performance**. Combine these techniques with **good state management** and **efficient rendering** for the **best results**.
